#Text=Giovanni Mangone
#Text=Palazzo
#Text=Massimo di Pirro in Rome ( today along Corso Vittorio Emanuele II ) is the only building still extant surely designed by Giovanni Mangone
#Text=Giovanni Mangone ( born towards the end of 15th century , died 25 June 1543 ) was an Italian artist active almost exclusively in Rome during the Renaissance .
#Text=Mangone 's skills were manifold : he worked as sculptor , architect , stonecutter and building estimator .
#Text=Moreover , he was a keen antiquarian and among the founders of the Academy dei Virtuosi al Pantheon .
#Text=As military engineer , he was renowned among his contemporaries .
#Text=Life and works
#Text=Tomb of Cardinal Willem van Enckevoirt at Santa Maria dell'Anima in Rome

#Text=Born around the end of the fifteenth century by Francesco , a native of Caravaggio in Lombardy , according to Giorgio Vasari he studied under sculptor and architect Andrea Ferrucci from Fiesole . [ 1 ]

#Text=In Rome , where he lived in a palace in via delle Coppelle , between Sant'Agostino and palazzo Baldassini , at the beginning of his career had several assignments ; from 1527 to 1532 he was superintendent to the spring of S. Peter ; until 1541 , he was curator of the gold-leaf ceiling of the Basilica of Santa Maria Maggiore ; since 1528 and until his death , he was architect of the apostolic Chamber . [ 1 ]
#Text=Moreover , during his whole career he worked also as building estimator . [ 1 ]

#Text=In 1534 started his collaboration with Antonio da Sangallo the Younger : together they prepared apparati effimeri in wood to celebrate the crowning of Pope Paul III ( r. 1534 – 49 ) and in 1536 , the visit to Rome of Holy Roman Emperor Charles V . [ 1 ]
#Text=In 1537 Mangone modified the monastery of the Servites near the Church of San Marcello al Corso , which he completed . [ 1 ]
#Text=However , due to subsequent changes in the seventeenth century , his work at the monastery is no longer recognizable . [ 1 ]
#Text=Perhaps since 1532 he designed for Angelo Massimo a palace south of Piazza Navona , in rione Parione . [ 1 ] [ 2 ]

#Text=The building , which in 1537 had been completed until its piano nobile , was erroneously named after king Pyrrhus of Epirus because of a statue ( actually of Mars ) once on display on a yard 's niche and now at the Musei Capitolini . [ 1 ]
#Text=The edifice is adjacent to the palace named Palazzo Massimo alle Colonne , realized in those years by Baldassare Peruzzi and commissioned by Angelo 's brother Pietro . [ 1 ] [ 2 ]
#Text=Palazzo Massimo di Pirro is Mangone 's only certain architectural work still extant . [ 1 ]
#Text=In this building his model is Antonio da Sangallo the Younger , of whom he adopts typological schemes and – partially – stylistic features . [ 1 ]

#Text=Anyway , in several elements , like the design of the irregular yard , the adoption of loggias with architrave , the usage of decorative elements as corbels , the equilibrium of the façade , he shows an original style . [ 1 ] [ 3 ] [ 2 ]

#Text=Based on stylistic analysis , have been attributed to him also the palazzo Alicorni in Borgo Vecchio ( later piazza Rusticucci ) in Borgo ( demolished in 1931 and later rebuilt ) and – more doubtfully – the Palazzetto De Vellis in Piazza Santa Maria in Trastevere . [ 1 ]

#Text=As a sculptor , only two works have been attributed to him : well-done appears to be the funerary monument to Cardinal Willem van Enckevoirt ( dead in 1534 ) in Santa Maria dell'Anima , where is evident an influence from Michelangelo , while that of the bishop of Chiusi and Governor of Bologna Gregorio Magalotti in Santa Cecilia in Trastevere , engraved in 1538 , radiates a cold feeling . [ 1 ]

#Text=As a military architect , in 1542 Mangone was summoned together with other architects by Paul III , who wanted to enhance the fortifications of Borgo , and in that occasion he presented a project . [ 1 ]
#Text=The following year he was active in Sermoneta , working at the town 's walls . [ 1 ]
#Text=Mangone was also a keen antiquarian , and collected in his palace a good deal of architectural and sculptural pieces . [ 1 ]

#Text=In 1543 , defining himself as a sculptor , he was among the founding members of the Congregation of " St. Joseph in the Holy Land at the Rotonda " , later known as the Accademia dei Virtuosi al Pantheon , one of the main centers of discussions about antiquities and architecture in Rome . [ 1 ]

column1: #Text=On 25 June 1543 he made his will , dying perhaps on the same day . [ 1 ]
#Text=Significance
#Text=Palazzo Alicorni ( here before its demolition in 1931 and later reconstruction ) could be attributed to Mangone because of its stylistic resemblance with the Palazzo di Pirro
#Text=As a sculptor , Mangone followed Andrea Sansovino , reaching mixed results . [ 1 ]
#Text=As an architect , his former education as a sculptor and stonemason in the design of moldings allowed him to reach a remarkable equilibrium of proportions . [ 1 ]
#Text=Moreover , Mangone was among the first to spread the " severe " style initiated by Antonio da Sangallo the Younger . [ 1 ]
#Text=With the Palazzo di Pirro , he designed a good example of " everyday " architecture which found many imitators in the second part of 16th century . [ 1 ]

#Text=As a military architect , although he was praised by the military engineer Francesco De Marchi , the absence of extant works which can be attributed to him makes difficult to assess its real contribution to this field . [ 1 ]
